bug.short_desc: It takes ages to display a report with label of very large font size.

long_desc.thetext:
Description: It takes ages to display a report with label of very large font size.
Steps to reproduce: 1. Insert two labels 2. Set one font weight to 100 and the other to 900 3. Preview in pdf/html
Expected result: Show different weight.
Actual result: In html, you can see font-weight effect In pdf, the report never displayed.
PS.If I change the font size to a small number, say 20, the report in pdf is generated immediated.
If setting a very large font size on text item, infinite loop occurs in PDF emitter. The same case exists in image item. Fix this bug.

bug.short_desc: a wired expection when preview the attached report [00]

long_desc.thetext:
Description: Please get the attached report design file, preview in the eclipse, a script error occurs.
Build Number: 2.2.0.v20061115-1059
Steps to reproduce: 1.Get the attached design file. 2.Preview in the designer, an error dispalys.
Expect result: No error.
Error log: There are errors evaluating script"This element has no methods."
Created an attachment (id=53893) report design file
The string 'This element has no methods.' is the OnPrepare script of lable. So it's expected result.
close this bug.

bug.short_desc: The default position issue for Library Explorer[01]

long_desc.thetext:
Description: The default position issue for Library Explorer.
Build number:2.2.0.v20061115-1059
Steps to reproduce: 1. Open Library Explorer view in main menu Window->Show View.
Expected result: The default position of library view had better in the below as Property Editor.
Actual result: It is in the position near Data Explorer. This position will cause inconvenience when conduct the operation like drag data source/dataset/parameter to report Data Explorer view directly.
Some users who are used to conduct similar operations in Data Explorer may be confused and I once processed a question from a user who don't know how to finish this operation because both views are parallel.
Of course this operation can be finished by drag datasource to Outline but change the position will make it more friendly.
Error log:N/A
I didn't know if we need change the default perspective. But I thought we can consider to reduce the views number by merge some of them.
please reopen this bug if there is more vote to change the current behavior.

bug.short_desc: [Regression]Truncated parameter default value[0705]

long_desc.thetext:
Description: Truncated display text parameter in the Parameter dialog.
Build Number: 2.2.0.v20061115-1059
Steps to reproduce: 1.The display type of report scalar parameter is "Combo Box", "static", and set the diplay text as "1111111111222222222222222444444444444445555555555555556999999999". 2.Preview, the parameter dialog pops up, you will see the display text is truncated.
Expected result: show the whole value for the parameter.

I think it is not a regression.Due to the different behaviours between IE and Mozilla. Mozilla can expand the item and show the whole item value, but IE will truncate the item. The width of select control( Combo box and list ) must be fixed. If it is auto width, it will cause other issues. For this issue, has added a tip on the select control if you mouse over it. Please check it.
It is not regression and this is the behavior is due to the difference of the browsers.

bug.short_desc: Empty Collections are not typecasted correctly

long_desc.thetext:
The following OCL expression should evaluate correctly: let v:Bag(String)=Bag{} in true
However, debugging the EMFT OCL code it shows that the Bag with no elements is actually a Bag(EClassifier) which is not conform to Bag(String) - but the Bag is also empty which allows one to cast it to any other bag as many examples in the OCL spec show. Note the above OCL expression is simplified for debugging. In reality I want to use it in an iterate expression to start with an empty accumulator collection...

Please use the MDT Product, UML2 OCL Component for reporting new bugs.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 164614 ***

I think this is solved with eclipse 3.3M7.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 157789 ***

bug.short_desc: Memory leak in Display SystemColor initialisation

long_desc.thetext: The system colors in Display are cached but the boolean flag to specify if the cache is ready is not updated after initializing the cache. This results in 13 colors being created on every getSystemColor call and these colors are never disposed!
The boolean flag is not correctly set to true after the initialization. The Colors will not be created repeatedly without being disposed in the end now. Thank you.

bug.short_desc: Error output when set format on parameter[0705]

long_desc.thetext:
Description: Set format on parameter, but it didn't display the correct output.
Build Number: 2.2.0.v20061115-1059
Steps to reproduce: 1.Create a report parameter, "Combo Box", "Static". 2.Add a value, such as value:ssff, display text:addd 3.Change its format as Uppercase. 4.Preview in birt. The output is "ssff".
Actual result: ssff
Expected result: SSFF
THe format is display format, instead of the output format in report. So 'ssff' is the expected result
Behavior is different if the display text of String parameter is "Text BOx" or "Combo Box".

Viewer should transfer the value without format to Engine. But for the text box and list box, it is difficult to know whether the value is changed by user in the input.So this could be a issue for the box which allow user to input.
for box input, if the input gains the focus, it should change the display to value. After it lost the focus, it should change the value to display.
*** Bug 165402 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

1) Support display text for text parameter. Current solution: Use an input hidden control to save parameter value (using default locale/format). The text field displays the display text value. If change the text field value, then refresh the parameter value using the changed text value and regard as the locale related parameter value. Add __islocale=ParameterName to indicate the current parameter value is a locale/format related string. Otherwise, the parameter value will be regarded as the standard (default locale/format) string.
2) Optimize the parameter parsed logic Avoid often open design handle to find the parameter handle. Adjust the JavaScript function to collect the parameter value.
Failed Test. The Actual result is still in lowercase.

Current designer logic is: If you don't enter display text, will use pattern to format value as display text. Else, the display text will be the input text. The format only acts on parameter value, not on display text. Viewer/Engine also follows this logic.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 155938 ***
duplicated bug.

bug.short_desc: Editors end up in starvation on openSUSE 10.2

long_desc.thetext: Unfortunately I can't be very explicit about the nature of the following issue as it seems to inherently prevent me from digging into it. What I discovered is that any kind of editor kind of starves in a wait state as soon as I try to open it. ViewParts seem to work nicely. I can't further investigate right now what causes this situation, because debugging is affected as well. I must say that I have this problem since I changed to openSUSE 10.2 which has Xorg 7.2 as a major change. The phenomenum does not occur in the 3.2 eclipse release though.
Can you get a stack trace to show us?

The problem lies somewhere within libswt-pi-gtk* when
public static final native void _gtk_enumerate_printers(int /*long*/ func, int /*long*/data, int /*long*/ destroy, boolean wait);
in class OS (from org.eclipse.swt.gtk.linux.x86) is called. It never returns (it doesn't raise an error either).
The parameters are: func -1549097609 data 0 destroy 0 wait true

Alexander, I think the NullPointerException is thrown, as you finally decide to close/abort Eclipse. By the way, I'm also using openSUSE 10.2 and this bug occurs here too. May it be more appropriate to report this on Novell's Bugzilla pages?
The same happens here. Gentoo (Gnome, sun-jdk1.5), so I don't believe it's related only to OpenSUSE

To those of you on this bug who are still experiencing this problem, can you please answer a couple of quesions for me:
1) Do you have any printers installed (using CUPS), and if so, can you print to them from another application?
2) What version of GTK are you using? (rpm -q gtk2)
Please also read bug 153936, and see if making any of the changes mentioned there (change to KDE if you are using Gnome, upgrade to a newer 2.10.x gtk, update your CUPS install, ...) make any difference for you.
The gtk2-2.10.6-24.2 from suse build service seems to have solved the issue, at least for me.
Having updated to gtk2-2.10.6-24.2 has solved the problem for me, too.

Carolyn, do you believe that this issue is fixed? Do we need to put in a GTK version check and enable printing only on "good" versions of GTK? It seems that I keep asking this question. Possibly, you've done this already and I keep forgetting?

Have a workaround for gtk_enumerate_printers - will post details in Bug 153936.

Created an attachment (id=53894) Complete console log
Tom could not that be caused by the change in boot delegation?

No, this is being caused by the changes to lazy-start and the Bundle.STARTING state that all bundles are in. I will investigate a fix.
BJ, this is one of the scenarios where it is difficult to tell if a bundle is in the STARTING state because it is waiting to lazy-start or because it is actually activating.

Created an attachment (id=53913) patch
Here is a fix. This patch uses the new Bundle.start(START_TRANSIENT) method to activate bundles instead of calling Bundle.loadClass. Pascal, please review.
Patch looks good.

Released fix to HEAD.
Markus, the fix is to the following plug-ins.
org.eclipse.core.runtime org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility
You can build from head or do you think this demands a rebuild of the I-Build?

I don't need a rebuild.
Profiling still works fine, I just can't jump from YourKit to Eclipse with a single click any more. I'll verify the fix in the next usable N-build.
I can only speak for myself, since I don't know under what circumstances other users/plug-ins are affected. But if have not heard from many others, I guess it's not an urgent problem.
Verified in I20061121-1845.

bug.short_desc: [enhancement] hot-keys for preview in web-viewer/html/pdf

long_desc.thetext: please add hot-keys/short-cuts to preview in web-viewer/html/pdf

There maybe more than two emitters exist to support preview in PDF(or html, etc), --this kind of possibility has been pointed out by engine. To this case, shall we define the short cut key point to a default emitter? If yes, which one should be default? In addition, for the output formats contributed through extension which are unkonwn to us and not under control by GUI development, do we add short cut key or not, and how?
Well the eninge need provide this kind of inof at emitter level.

I think it's strange to add hot-keys/short-cuts in emitter. emitter is not only used in designer, it's also for Engine Runtime. Moreover, emitter doesn't know anything about the caller and other emitters, conflict can not be avoided if defining hot-keys/short-cuts in emitter.

bug.short_desc: The inferred element type of an empty collection is wrong

long_desc.thetext:
The inferred element type of an empty collection literal (e.g. Set{}) should be OclVoid and should thus conform to all other types. This is not the case unfortunately. The following should work, but it does not:
let a:Set(Integer)=Set{} in a
Error message: 'Init expression type does not conform to type of variable (a).'

The following does work
let a:Set(Integer)=Set{1,3,2} in a
which returns 2 1 3
*** Bug 164605 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

The inferred element type of empty collection literals is now OclVoid. This will result in the correct generalization of the element type to something more interesting when elements are "added" to it (note that "adding" actually creates new collections).

bug.short_desc: [JFace] ToolTip should respect Display.boundaries

long_desc.thetext: Native tooltip are always drawn that they are completely visible on the display. Our tooltips don't do that currently
We should also be aware of monitor bounds in dual monitor setups as well.
Created an attachment (id=53990) Patch to respect display/monitor bounds
By the way TreeViewer likely has the same problem.

(In reply to comment #3) > By the way TreeViewer likely has the same problem. >
sorry wrong bug ;-)
Created an attachment (id=53992) Patch to respect display/monitor bounds and make DefaultToolTip reusable
Fix for ToolTip submitted.
Verified in I20061212-0010 that the fix works for display bounds but not for monitor bounds. They will span monitors.

After setting the respectMonitorBounds flag to true (oops) it still doesn't work. While the tip doesn't span monitors it always appears on monitor 0 irregardless of where the mouse is.
Two issues:
1) the flag should be set to true by default 2) it should work ;)
If you need help with this let me know - I have dual monitor setups for Win, Mac, and Linux if need be for testing purposes.

Created an attachment (id=55643) a first try to fix problem
Kim could please give this patch a try I think it should solve the problem with more than one monitor, the former problem was that the controls monitor was used to determine which monitor the tooltip is placed on.
I cant check it out right now but it looks sensible. Checking it in.
Verified by Benny in I20070206-0010

attachment.desc: Patch to respect display/monitor bounds and make DefaultToolTip reusable
a first try to fix problem

bug.short_desc: WSDL Editor, Outline View -> Imports -> Import does not work for files of registered contentypes other than wsdl or xsd

long_desc.thetext:
Despite registered content types it isn't possible to import corresponding files via the Outline of the WSDL editor.
The different content types where registered as follows in the corresponding pluging.xml
...
<extension point="org.eclipse.core.runtime.contentTypes"> <content-type priority="high" name="SOPware Service Description" id="org.sopware.content.type.sdx" base-type="org.eclipse.wst.wsdl.wsdlsource" default-charset="UTF-8" file-extensions="sdx" /> <content-type priority="high" name="SOPware Service Provider Description" id="org.sopware.content.type.spdx" base-type="org.eclipse.wst.wsdl.wsdlsource" default-charset="UTF-8" file-extensions="spdx" /> </extension>
...
Similar faults: 143734; 154850

Rich, it seems the import location selection dialog uses an file extension based filter to only display *.wsdl and *.xsd workspace resources. We could probably change it to allow all extensions registered for the WSDL content type and any derived content types. It would be also interesting to know whether the model will properly load these new files. If not, we may need to do some tricks with the EMF resource set used by the editor.

Yep currently EMF doesn't support any notion of content type, so if we wanted to support additional file extensions we'd need to be careful that our model related code doesn't barf (we'd need to make sure imports/includes of other file extensions work too).

bug.short_desc: Eclipse 3.2.1 segvaults on libcairo.so.2

long_desc.thetext:
I have had Eclipse 3.2.1 crashing on me randomly for some days now. Actually it's the JVM that seems to crash. There doesn't seem to be any particular event that triggers the crash, but it's totallly random. Sometimes it crashes right after startup and sometimes you can go on with your work for some 10-30 minutes. Sometimes even for hours. I'll include on of the crash log files here, but I have tons of those in my /tmp if someone is interested. I'm running FC6 with libcairo 1.2.6. On thing that seems to be common in all of the crash logs is the address after libcairo.so.2+... which seems to vary only a little. Usually it's 16145 but I've seen atleast the address 1614b also.

bug.short_desc: Define interaction between name resolution and index

long_desc.thetext:
I am trying to understand the interaction between the name resolution 'CPPSemantics.resolveBinding(IASTName)' and the index. I see 3 different paths on how the index is used:
(1) During the (scope-local) lookup in a namespace (CPPScope.getBinding(...)) (2) implicitly via IScope.getBinding(...) in case a name resolution introduces a scope stored in the index. (3) At the end of the lookup (CPPSemantics.postResolution()), if no result has been found by other means.
From that, it is not clear to me, what the index is expected to return on (3). Does it really have to analyze the context in which the name is used in the AST?
I think it would be more natural to use the index during the (scope-local) lookup in a translation unit, similar to (1) in CPPScope.getBinding(..). I even think that it is not correct moving on without consulting the index there. Doing that should make (3) superfluous. Furthermore, the index would return global symbols, only and does not have to inspect the context of the IASTName.

I agree with Marcus. I have not looked at how the PDOM was integrated beyond the one postResolution() method (see bug 164481). The last thing you want is for the PDOM to essentially duplicate the kind of analysis that goes on in CPPSemantics and CPPVisitor in order to return a binding.
If the PDOM is going to be correct in the long run, it should only be consulted in a "scope restricted" manner, that is (1) and (2). As well, it should realize that finding nothing is often in fact the correct answer. The bindings it returns should be indistinguishable from regular bindings as far as the semantic resolution is concerned, in particular with regard to IType information (see for example bug 164659).

There is no doubting that the PDOM integration with the resolution algorithms is a big hack. Ideally, yes, the PDOM should be integrated much earlier than it is, i.e. at namespace lookup time. However, I find the resolution code mind boggling and full of assumptions that we have an AST around to help with the lookups. I couldn't see an easy way to integrate the PDOM there.

The scopes were introduced as a kind of cache for the bindings to improve performance. The PDOM should really be considered as an extension of this.
You can consider the resolution to be in 2 parts, the first is to collect a set of bindings to consider, the second is to actually choose between them. Collecting bindings comes from either the physical tree, or from the scopes.
In theory, resolving between the bindings does not need the physical information although in practice there are likely some places that would need to be changed (In particular, CPPSemantics.declaredBefore would need to do the right thing for PDOM bindings). There do exist bindings that have no physical information at all.
I am giving this a shot. My first attempts look promising.

Created an attachment (id=54725) Suggested change
The patch changes the way the index is acessed during the CPP name resolution. It fixes a few test-cases and passes all existing ones.
I can index firefox without exceptions and it fixes 64.000 problems. That sounds a lot, but there are 512.000 problems left. Although the name lookups are faster the overall time of indexing firefox increases, mainly because there is more data to insert into the index. See the details below.
Before Patch: PDOMFastReindex firefox-2.0 (2426 sources, 4075 headers) PDOMFastReindex Timings: 856704 total, 838820 parser, 124829 resolution, 431671 index update. PDOMFastReindex Result: 521625 declarations, 1537279 references, 2 errors, 576105 problems.
after applying patch: PDOMFastReindex firefox-2.0 (2428 sources, 4075 headers) PDOMFastReindex Timings: 914080 total, 913015 parser, 103595 resolution, 533596 index update. PDOMFastReindex Result: 524099 declarations, 1596243 references, 0 errors, 512334 problems.

I've had a look at the patch, this is what I've seen.. (1) revision of isSameType on DOM and PDOM classes (2) support for implicit methods (3) support for pointer-to-member-types and array-types (4) removal of access to the IASTInitializer for default parameters, replaced with boolean to check whether the parameter had a default value (5) changes to index based binding resolution
I'm happy with (1)-(4), and (5) looks good, although I've not understood all of it
My two questions would be.. (1) In CPPSemantics.resolveAmbiguities, is there an assumption that either all function candidates come from the AST or all functions come from the index? if so, I'd've thought that might be a problem?
(2) are PDOMCPPLinkage.resolveBinding and PDOMCPPLinkage._resolveBinding needed?

Thanks for the feedback! (In reply to comment #6) > My two questions would be.. > (1) In CPPSemantics.resolveAmbiguities, is there an assumption that either all > function candidates come from the AST or all functions come from the index? if > so, I'd've thought that might be a problem? No, theoretically that should work with a combination of both. For the case where there are candidates from the AST I wrote the code such that it ignores the candidates from the index. In 99% of the cases that should be the right thing to do.
> (2) are PDOMCPPLinkage.resolveBinding and PDOMCPPLinkage._resolveBinding > needed? At this point they are still being used, but we should get rid of them. I think it is not hard to do so and I will look into this before applying the patch.

I have commited the patch, here a summary of what it does: (1) cpp-name resolution makes scope-local lookups to the index, only. (2) IType.isSameType works accross DOM and PDOM classes (3) a general mechanism to prevent stack overflows during the name resolution (4) removal of access to the IASTInitializer for default parameters (5) extensions to the index: implicit methods, pointer-to-member-types, array-types, reference types, return types, default parameters.
The fix reduces the problem count for indexing firefox 2.0 from 576105 to 512334 problems.

bug.short_desc: [api] rse.files.ui and shells.ui should not depend on debug.core

long_desc.thetext:
The plugins org.eclipse.files.ui and org.eclipse.shells.ui have a hard dependency to org.eclipse.debug.core. This is problematic for minimal (RCP) installations which should be able to run without debug.core installed.
The dependency to org.eclipse.debug.core is only needed in order to perform source lookups which are configured through an associated project: in other words, as long as the API call IRemoteCommandShell.associateProject(IProject) is never called, the corresponding code can never be executed.
Moreover, the code actually doing the source lookups is duplicated in three places: * SystemEditProjectFileLineAction * SystemRemoteFileLineOpenWithMenu * SystemViewRemoteOutputAdapter
It would be better to introduce a new interface e.g. IRemoteSourceLookupProvider, which has an implementation being declared in an additional plugin especially dedicated to debugging (e.g. org.eclipse.rse.debug). Then, * only the additional plugin (org.eclipse.rse.debug) would need to have the dependencies into org.eclipse.debug.core; it would be possible to provide a "minimal" RSE without debugging facilities. * A different default implementation of IRemoteSourceLookupProvider could be provided in rse.core, just parsing workspace resource names and doing a default lookup (but without using any facilities from debug.core). * the duplicated code for executing the source lookup could be kept in only one place in the rse.debug plugin * We would most probably need an additional API IRemoteCommandShell.associateSourceLookup(IRemoteSourceLookupProvider)
For users of the existing functionality, migration would be rather easy: wherever they used to do IRemoteCommandShell.associateProject(proj); they would now need to do IRemoteCommandShell.associateProject(proj); IRemoteCommandShell.associateSourceLookup(new RSEDebugSourceLookup(proj));
Please comment on this proposal.
-----------Enter bugs above this line----------- RSE 1.0 Release Test installation : eclipse-SDK-3.2.1 RSE install : update-site RSE 1.0 complete java.runtime : Sun 1.5.0_08-b03 os.name: : Windows XP 5.1, Service Pack 1 ------------------------------------------------ systemtype : Windows-local, Dstore-win, Dstore-linux targetos : Red Hat Enterprise Linux WS release 4 (Nahant Update 3) targetuname : Linux parser 2.6.9-34.EL #1 i686 athlon i386 GNU/Linux targetvm : Sun Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.4.2_12-b03, mixed mode) ------------------------------------------------

This is now fixed. The dependency existed due to obsolete code that had been used to associate a local project resource (not temp files) with a remote error or file. The debug source lookup mechanism had been used for that purpose however that approach is no longer in use.

So when I get you right, the user-visible impact of this change is this:
When doing a command like "gcc -c myFile.c" in a Remote Shell, and the command produces some error output, selecting the line and choosing Open With > Editor will now ALWAYS navigate to the remote file.
Before that change, it was possible to associate a local project with the remote shell, and configure a debug source lookup that would allow navigating to the local workspace resource instead. But, since associating the project was only possible programmatically in openRSE, the users would not see any change.
Correct?

Right. This stuff was once exposed to the user via RSE external tools and RSE external build. A local project could be associated with the shell that was used to run a build command and the remote file for an error could be mapped back to a file in the local project via a source lookup in that project. Given that EFS seems to be the way things will go for remote project-oriented stuff, this approach would probably be the wrong way to go if/when we brought RSE external tools into open source. It probably makes sense to get rid of the associateProject() api as well.

Hmm... I'm not sure EFS is the only solution for remote build.
In my opinion, a *local* workspace that gets synchronized to the remote side (through an RSE export operation, rsync or similar) before building remotely is more effective because it is much better suited for local tooling (static analysis, parsers, config management etc) -- at least in some scenarios, the remote side will be used for build only. [There may be others where static analysis, CM etc. are done remotely.]
Therefore, adding back some sort of source lookup for remote errors might be interesting in the future. But if that is done, it should be done in a manner that avoids dependencies on debug in the core (and injects a source lookup mechanism from a separate plugin).

Actually, I do agree about the usefulness of a local "replica" project that is associated with one or more remote targets. I've been involved in several discussions about this in the past and I do see it's value over the 1-to-1 mapping that an EFS project would be limited to. Regarding source lookup, though, I imagine that there would be a more optimal way of associating build errors with the associated replica project resource.
Amen :-)

bug.short_desc: Program throws java.lang.IncompatibleClassChangeError

long_desc.thetext:
No I did not want to match the inner class. In the programming guide for Type pattern I found: An embedded * in an identifier matches any sequence of characters, but does not match the package (or inner-type) separator. So I expected test.* to only match normal classes but no inner classes.
There was no AJDT marker on the inner class. So i thought the inner class is not a target. If I change the declaration to : declare parents: (test.* || test.*.* ) && !BoundEntityAspect implements BoundBean;
I see an annotation on the inner class.
How I can prevent this in the declare clause to match only top classes?

I have found and fixed the problem. The programming guide is correct - my previous comment was to give you perhaps something of a workaround by specifying perhaps something like 'test.* && !test.*.*' if you wanted to progress past this problem whilst I worked on it (wasn't sure how hard it would be to fix).
The problem was the front end compiler considering your pattern matched the inner type but the backend weaver (correctly) not seeing it as a match. So it parsed just fine but then the weaver produced a broken class file. (so the reason you saw no AJDT marked in your original version is that it is the weaver that produces those and that didn't consider it a match)
I am committing this for 1.5.3 final - it is quite a nasty bug.
Changing OS from Mac OS to Mac OS X as per bug 185991

bug.short_desc: JUnit/Plug-in tests do not allow default package names.

long_desc.thetext:
JUnit/Plug-in tests do not allow default package names.
JUnit/Plug-in test wizards do not force the user to specify a package name.
When the user creates a JUnit/Plug-in test with a default package (e.g. empty value), the test class generator displays an error that the package a cannot be empty. This is a problem for several reasons:
1) It is a regression since users were permitted to use the default package in previous versions.
2) JDT permits classes to be created in the default package.
3) Users may want to use the default package.
4) The JUnit/Plug-in test wizard allows the user to specify the default package (e.g. empty value) (the user is only warned that the default package is discouraged).
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 160970 ***
ACTION: Please verify/close this defect.
Reporter: Please verify and close in preparation for shutting down the TPTP 4.4 release. Thanks.

Closing by default since not verified/closed by the originator in the 6+ months since being resolved.
Please reopen if the issue is still present in the latest TPTP release or the resolution is not correct.

bug.short_desc: Deadlock in Test Navigator

long_desc.thetext: A deadlock has been reported on some machines (see bugzilla 157089). The UI thread stack is the following when the deadlock occurs: Collections$SynchronizedSet(Collections$SynchronizedCollection).add(Object) line: not available FileProxyNodeCache.addResourceListener(IResourceChangeListener) line: 284 DefaultTypeProvider.<init>() line: 48 TypeProviderManager$DefaultTypeProviderInfo.<init>(TypeProviderManager, String) line: 111 TypeProviderManager.getTypeProviderProxyNode(IProject, String) line: 183 LogicalTestNavigatorProvider.getTypeProviders(IProject) line: 85 LogicalTestNavigatorProvider.getChildren(Object) line: 68 TreeViewer(AbstractTreeViewer).getRawChildren(Object) line: 1166 TreeViewer.getRawChildren(Object) line: 768 TreeViewer(AbstractTreeViewer).getFilteredChildren(Object) line: 574 TreeViewer(AbstractTreeViewer).getSortedChildren(Object) line: 543 . .

Created an attachment (id=53908) Fix
Here's the patch to the deadlock issue.
I assume this is for Julien since he already has a fix for it.

Although the patch resolves the initial issue that I reported, I found another case where the test perspective hangs the workbench.
When I check-out test-results/platform/org.eclipse.hyades.use.cases from TPTP's cvs and switch to the Test perspective, the workbench hangs with my CPU maxed out. An out of memory exception is eventually thrown.
I'm not sure if it matters or not but the 'logical' toolbar item of the test navigator was enabled before I checked out the plug-in.
I verified that this patch works in my scenario. I no longer get a dead lock.

(In reply to comment #3)
Ali, please provide the stack trace.

(In reply to comment #3) > When I check-out test-results/platform/org.eclipse.hyades.use.cases from TPTP's > cvs and switch to the Test perspective, the workbench hangs with my CPU maxed > out. An out of memory exception is eventually thrown.
There are two other bugzillas that may track this problem: 160224 TestNavigator: proxies should not use the common resource... 160221 [Performance] TestNavigator: Large execution results display is excessively slow These two fixes (which were deferred to 4.4) address some performance & memory issues.

Since this problem only occurs on specific platforms (e.g. not exposed during i3 TP1) and cannot be consistently reproduced, decrease the severity to major to match the other related defects (160224, 160221 and 157089). Furthermore, since the fix for this defect does not cover all problem scenarios and may introduce negative side effects due to the nature of the fix, deferring to 4.4. All four defects (160224, 160221 and 157089) will be fixed at the beginning of the release to ensure thorough testing during the release's test passes.

(In reply to comment #5) > Ali, please provide the stack trace.
A stack trace won't be of any use for the scenario that I've mentioned in comment#3. The hang is not being cause by a deadlock. There is activity because my CPU is being maxed out. I get a different stack trace when the main thread is paused. I suspect that there is an infinite loop that we never step out of.
(In reply to comment #7) Actually the problem is consistently reproducible on machines where the deadlock happens and it is not platform specific. As discussed with Paul, I don't think this should have been deferred to 4.4. Hanging the workbench can result in the lost of unsaved resources/preferences/etc...

(In reply to comment #8) I get a different stack trace when the main > thread is paused. I suspect that there is an infinite loop that we never step > out of. I still think this is a different issue related to performance, not to an infinite loop. At the end of 4.3i2, I spent some time profiling the test navigator to identify performance issues, and I worked with the project org.eclipse.hyades.logging.core.tests (which contains very large test logs). The initial discovery of the project's content, on a decent machine, takes about 80 minutes. The main issue was in ICU code, in which 80% of time is spent. Decorators are also a major slowdown. After a few optimizations (mainly by adopting a "lazy" strategy), the time falls to 4 minutes. This issue is tracked in https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=160221.

(In reply to comment #8)
I was looking for the stack trace of the memory exception.

(In reply to comment #7)
Based on Ali's prompting, Julien and I reviewed this defect again and we concur with Ali. Although we could not reproduce/verify Bob's scenario (and he is equally busy with unrelated 4.3 deliverables so he could not test Julien's fix), Julien's fix does resolve both Sheldon and Ali's issue. After a thorough review of Julien fix, we are proposing that this defect be committed in 4.3. As such, retargetting and raising the severity to critical since is some cases, data loss is experienced.

bug.short_desc: API Recorder's probe script/classes are not built/packaged.

long_desc.thetext:
API Recorder's probe script/classes are not built/packaged.
The org.eclipse.hyades.probekit.probekitbuilder builder is not being invoked correctly during the build of the API Recorder (org.eclipse.tptp.test.tools.api plugin). As a result, the following files are missing from the root of the api.recorder.jar JAR thereby breaking API recording:
APIRecorderProbe.probeinfo APIRecorderProbe.probescript APIRecorderProbe_probe$Probe_0.class APIRecorderProbe_probe.class

This defect was only found when testing with the build/packaged plugin. Testing with the self-hosted instance of the plugin/workbench did not expose this defect since the org.eclipse.hyades.probekit.probekitbuilder builder was automatically invoked before execution.
Hubert, can you look at this problem?

bug.short_desc: Targets cannot be added to probes loaded from a JAR file.

long_desc.thetext:
Targets cannot be added to probes loaded from a JAR file.
When the API Recorder loads the APIRecorderProbe.probe resource in the api.recorder.jar JAR, Targets cannot be added to the loaded resource. As a result, the user cannot specify custom targets in the API Recorder UI. Although this appears to be an EMF issue (EMF defect to follow) not covered by defect 84327, this defect is for the API Recorder will work-around this issue (loading the probe resource from a serialized version of probe).
This defect was only found when testing with the build/packaged plugin. Testing with the self-hosted instance of the plugin/workbench did not expose this defect since the APIRecorderProbe.probe resource was not packaged in a JAR.

bug.short_desc: Border items sometimes hop around bordering shape

long_desc.thetext:
The BorderItemLocator positions the border item with a constraint relative to the topleft corner of the border item figure's parent figure. The BorderItemSelectionEditPolicy creates a move command to set the constraint relative to the topleft corner of the border item editpart's parent figure. If the border item figure's parent is not the border item editpart's parent figure then these do not work together.
I am attaching a patch for the BorderItemSelectionEditPolicy that creates a move command to set the constraint relative to the topleft corner of the border item figure's parent figure.
Created an attachment (id=53910) Suggested fix, not code reviewed yet.
Committed the patch.

bug.short_desc: TextSearchVisitor.search(..) notifies progress monitor in wrong thread

long_desc.thetext:
I20061114-1636
TextSearchVisitor.search(IFile[], IProgressMonitor) creates a new Job and notifies the progress monitor in another thread. This causes problems when the progress monitor expects to be called in the UI Thread.
E.g. when I rename a type with the "rename in editor" feature and enable "Update fully qualified names in non-java files", I get an error dialog and the exception below. The problem is that RenameLinkedMode.doRename(..) starts the refactoring with the workbench window as context and the StatusLine apparently cannot handle progress updates from other threads.
!ENTRY org.eclipse.core.jobs 4 2 2006-11-15 14:59:05.061 !MESSAGE An internal error occurred during: "Search progress polling". !STACK 0 org.eclipse.swt.SWTException: Invalid thread access at org.eclipse.swt.SWT.error(SWT.java:3407) at org.eclipse.swt.SWT.error(SWT.java:3330) at org.eclipse.swt.SWT.error(SWT.java:3301) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.error(Display.java:1001) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.checkDevice(Display.java:661) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.getSystemColor(Display.java:1991) at org.eclipse.jface.action.StatusLine.updateMessageLabel(StatusLine.java:640) at org.eclipse.jface.action.StatusLine.setMessage(StatusLine.java:530) at org.eclipse.jface.action.StatusLine.setMessage(StatusLine.java:518) at org.eclipse.jface.action.StatusLine.subTask(StatusLine.java:599) at org.eclipse.jface.action.StatusLineManager$1.subTask(StatusLineManager.java:207) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.ProgressMonitorWrapper.subTask(ProgressMonitorWrapper.java:156) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.SubProgressMonitor.subTask(SubProgressMonitor.java:170) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.ProgressMonitorWrapper.subTask(ProgressMonitorWrapper.java:156) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.SubProgressMonitor.subTask(SubProgressMonitor.java:170) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.ProgressMonitorWrapper.subTask(ProgressMonitorWrapper.java:156) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.SubProgressMonitor.subTask(SubProgressMonitor.java:170) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.ProgressMonitorWrapper.subTask(ProgressMonitorWrapper.java:156) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.SubProgressMonitor.subTask(SubProgressMonitor.java:170) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.ProgressMonitorWrapper.subTask(ProgressMonitorWrapper.java:156) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.SubProgressMonitor.subTask(SubProgressMonitor.java:170) at org.eclipse.search.internal.core.text.TextSearchVisitor$1.run(TextSearchVisitor.java:148) at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:58)

The job has been introduced to fix bug 86963. I think to only way to solve both problems would be to invert the usage of the two threads, i.e. use the calling thread for progress notifications and do the actual search in the job.

- I don't think one is forced to serve a progress monitor in the same thread. At least this isn't specified by the progress monitor - In your case, why do you execute the search operation in the UI thread? That's something that should be avoided in general

> - I don't think one is forced to serve a progress monitor in the same thread. > At least this isn't specified by the progress monitor
Hard to tell, the section "The workbench and threads" in http://help.eclipse.org/help32/index.jsp?topic=/org.eclipse.platform.doc.isv/guide/swt_threading.htm says that in general, Platform/UI APIs assume they're called in the UI thread unless noted otherwise.
> - In your case, why do you execute the search operation in the UI thread? > That's something that should be avoided in general
I'm investigating; I guess I can indeed set fork=true in my use case, which would solve this particular problem.

IProgressMonitor is org.eclipse.core.runtime. Operations are typically implemented in core which doesn't know of the concept of the UI thread.
I think we could also file this against platform UI. They normally already have progress monitors that forward calls with sync exec.

> I think we could also file this against platform UI. They normally already have > progress monitors that forward calls with sync exec.
Hm, they already do, but it's not possible in this case: In ModalContext.run(..), if fork is false, the operation must be run in the current thread (which is the UI thread in our case). If they would wrapper the progress monitor into an AccumulatingProgressMonitor, then updates would only occur in an asyncExec, which is only executed when the whole refactoring operation returns (i.e. progress bar is not redrawn at all...).

bug.short_desc: FunctionStyleMacro-expansion error

long_desc.thetext:
Example: " #define DEFAULT_C_PATH /usr/include #define MAKE_INCLUDE(path, header) <path/header> #include MAKE_INCLUDE(DEFAULT_C_PATH, temp.h) "
expands to " #include </usr/include/header> "
Cause/Solution:
org.eclipse.cdt.internal.core.parser.scanner2.BaseScanner.java method expandFunctionStyleMacro(...) line 4401: (tries to look for a beginning comment; please note the ++pos) > c = expansion[++pos]; but at line 4426: (Oops, it was not a comment!) fails to reset the position ( --pos; // is the missing statement)
Without this, it searches the macro expansion from 'eader' (example above) and fails to match it against the header argument. This correction was also tested on solaris (without this you can't compile anything on SunOs5.9).
Let me know, if you need future support for the fix Ben.
Thanks Istvan for the perfect analysis! Added testcase and fix > 20061115.

bug.short_desc: [Dialogs] ProgressMonitorDialog's ProgressMonitor is not thread safe

long_desc.thetext:
Every IProgressMonitor has an internal state that is usually shared between two or more threads. That state is the canceled flag, that can be set "outside" of a long running operation (e.g. by the UI thread if the user presses the cancel button) and queried inside it (by the worker thread).
Although the concrete realization of an IProgressMonitor is implementation dependent and not every IProgressMonitor has to be thread safe, some existing implementations - like that in ProgressMonitorDialog (jface) - already violate thread safety due to unsynchronized access of the "canceled" state variable.

The IProgressMonitor is an interface and it has no way to to force whe implementation details.
I am not familiar with JFace code and ProgressMonitorDialog in particular. However, please keep in mind that even if underlying variable keeping the "cancelled" state is not atomic, it is not important to propagate the "cancelled" state right away. Threads should poll those values often enough.
Closing. If you feel that ProgressMonitorDialog implementation should be fixed, please open a bug for it (or modify this one).

OK, I've now concretized the subject: JFace's ProgressMonitorDialog is not using a thread safe IProgressMonitor implementation although the "canceled" state is accessed by multiple threads. The problem is not atomicity as mentioned in comment #1, but visibility! If one thread sets cancelled to true, this change might never become visible to the worker thread.
This bug could be solved by simple defining the state variable fIsCanceled as volatile. Other state variables might be affected too, but I've not inspected them yet.

This got me curious and I dug out this document:
http://java.sun.com/docs/books/jls/second_edition/html/memory.doc.html
If I am interpreting right what it says, it is up to Java implementation to decide when to push modified non-volatile variable from the thread memory into the main memory. Is this correct?
I though that the thread memory and main memory always gets reconciled, maybe not right away, but, in human perception terms, fast enough. However, if I am reading this document correctly, it's completely up to VM to decide when (and if) values are propagated to the main memory.
Out of curiosity, do you see this behavior actually happening? What VM are you using?

See discussion in bug 162673. Theoretically there is no bound on the time a thread can have a cached stale copy of a variable. In practice, I think this never happens for a span of more than a few milliseconds. I.e., unless you have a race condition in which stale values will cause a failure, this shouldn't be a problem. Unsynchronized reads of shared variables is extremely common. Note also that there is a performance cost to either synchronization or volatile, so we shouldn't be slapping it everywhere based on theory. Mario, let us know if you have observed an actual problem here.

No, I have not observed any problems with thread synchronization on shared progress monitors (so far). I was just investigating the mechanisms eclipse uses to solve concurrency issues when I stumbled across this IProgressMonitor implementation, wondering if it was on purpose or just a bug (or I've overlooked something).
So please set this bug to "WONTFIX" (or "INVALID" if you do not consider it as bug).
But I do not agree with you about the question how often / how long stale data may exist. Of course, it is very unlikely nowadays on single CPUs, but the trend goes toward having many processors with moderate power. To achive best performance on such systems, JVM vendors will tie threads to CPUs - so shared variables will be held in hardware caches. I'm sure, JVM vendors will exploit the margins of the java memory model to get the most out of it - this might mean to not synchronize at all if the program does not enforce it.
By the way, thread synchonization using the "synchronized" statement of declaring variables as volatile is far not so performance cost-intensive as man might think. Especially in Java 5.0 one focus was on improving performance of thread synchronization mechanisms. And as far as I know, the guys did a very good job (accessing "volatile" variables is not much slower than accessing "normal" variables); unfortunately, I do not have concrete numbers.
Marking WONTFIX

bug.short_desc: [DataBinding] Ensure and document thread safety

long_desc.thetext:
Now that we're a multithreaded library we need to ensure that we are thread safe and that thread safety is documented.
A couple of methods that are not thread safe: * Policy#getLog() * Policy#setLog(...) * AbstactObservable#dispose()
add/remove listener methods should be made thread safe too.

I started looking at ths and we probably also want to check for the current realm in: * setValue * fire*Event
The only issue is that in order to provide this check in setValue we'll need to make it final and provide a template method like in getValue. This will break all observable value implementations. I don't mind doing it, just want to make sure you don't have other plans/ideas.

On the Nov. 30th data binding call we agreed that we need to follow the same pattern for setValue as we did for getValue (make setValue final and provide a doSetValue template method). We also need to make changes to ObservableSet, ObservableList, etc.
Target Milestone is 3.3M4

Created an attachment (id=54950) doSetValue patch
Changes to AbstractObservableValue and all observables to implement doSetValue. The only unexpected change was creating doSetApprovedValue(...) in AbstractVetoableValue to ensure that the consumer didn't override doSetValue.
Patch released >20061204.
I've got a little more work to do. I need to apply the same concepts to lists, sets, and trees as well.
I didn't get all of this in for 3.3M4, pushing to 3.3M5.

I'm going to have to push the rest of this to M6. I doubt I'll have time to complete it before M5. I don't believe that there were any API changes needed. I just need to go through and checking realms and synchronizing listeners for Sets.
Moving to 3.3M7.
VERIFIED in I20070502-1336

bug.short_desc: General - Getting Started content needs better alignment to OpenUP/Basic disciplines and target audience

long_desc.thetext:
This item was reported as a result of the 11/15 OpenUP alignment review.
This is more introductory than getting started content - move some to Introduction page Move "What is OpenUP/Basic?" to the Introduction page This material is redundant with the Roadmap introduction and should be merged with it. Move "Who Should Use OpenUP/Basic?" to the Introduction page
Use "How Do I Get Started?" section as the basis for the new OpenUP Roadmap for Practitioners This basic format would work as an outline to describe how someone would deploy the process in their environment. See the description of the OpenUP Roadmap for Practitioners below for details.
Describe or link to descriptions of important concepts Roles Milestones Phases Iterations Artifacts The WIL and use cases should be referenced as primary artifacts
Explain why there's no Deployment, Environment, or Configuration Management disciplines
OpenUP Roadmap Most of this content is introductory material and should be moved to the Introduction page. See the comments on the Introduction to OpenUP/Basic page for specific information. The purpose of the roadmap should be to quickly get practitioners quickly using OpenUP/Basic out of the box. Rename "OpenUP Roadmap for Practitioners" Subtitles should use the common capitalization format All words capitalized except minor ones (the, in, etc). Move Introduction section to the Introduction to OpenUP/Basic page Move the Organization section to the Introduction to OpenUP/Basic page Move the Software Development Lifecycle section to the Getting Started page New Content The roadmap should include the following content. Indicate that this page is for practitioners to get running quickly with OpenUP/Basic Explain how visual modeling can be removed from the process and the effect of doing so Explain how to modify the process Minor modifications only such as changing text and adding and contributing pages. Subtopic
Move the About and Copyright nodes so they're under the Introduction node
Create New Guidance: Resources for Modifying Methods Describe resources and links that can be used to get help on modifying OpenUP/Basic. Create New Guidance: Resources for Contributing to OpenUP Link to resources that describe how to contribute to EPF and OpenUP.

One thing to consider when looking at the getting started page is how would you demo OpenUP to a group of people? I demoed it last week and found that I would have really liked to have the lifecycle/phases diagram on that main page directly below the round table graphic. A bit of text would have been good too.
My advice: 1. Identify several key diagrams. 2. Provide some overview text. 3. Provide links from the diagrams. 4. Provide a list of key links at the bottom of the page in case people don't like to click on diagrams.

The insertion of
"Explain how to modify the process Minor modifications only such as changing text and adding and contributing pages."
IMO is not of interest of people using OpenUP/Basic in their projects - the practitioners. This content would fit better in an method authoring method.
Other than that, I'm fine with swapping text as proposed here.
I will use this issue to manage the re-organization of the getting started content.

Created an attachment (id=56870) Draft outline for getting started
This outline assumes the existence of other resources (e.g. white papers) that will provide a more detailed overview of how to get started.

Created an attachment (id=56872) Revised getting started with lifecycle content
Revised getting started outline by moving lifecycle from introduction to getting started
Reassign to Jim Ruehlin as agreed during Friday January 19th telecon.

I suggest the Getting Started item should illustrate the practices, team configuration, and rigor necessary to adopt OpenUP/Basic. The Roadmap should lay out a typical or easy scenario for deploying OpenUP/Basic to a small team. In other words, Getting Started introduces concepts and context. The Roadmap describes how to actually do it.

The Getting Started page has been outlined and should be reviewed and modified for E2. It can be detailed in Construction. The Roadmap page should probably be moved to a new bugzilla so it can be tracked separately. Some old content from the Getting Started page was moved to the Roadmap page so it can be used in that context.

Many of the changes from comment #1 have been made. It now seems like the roadmap provides a sufficient overview and should be retained until we decide to do something better. Recommend closing this bugzilla.
Verifying in accordance to comment #9.
Verified - closing out bug.

attachment.desc: Revised getting started with lifecycle content

bug.short_desc: General - Introduction needs better alignment to OpenUP/Basic disciplines and target audience

long_desc.thetext:
This item was reported as a result of the 11/15 OpenUP alignment review.
Reorganize the page to highlight important concepts and keep them "above the fold" Move OpenUP logo to upper left of window Move quicklinks below the OpenUP logo Place minimal/complete/extensible text to the right of the logo as the first thing users see Place descriptions of subprocesses under the minimal/complete/extensible text
This page needs a description introducing OpenUP/Basic There is no introductory material on this page. See the the comments to the OpenUP Roadmap for more information (bug https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=164654). Explain what makes OpenUP/Basic what it is Describe what minimal/complete/extensible means to the practitioner Make a distinction between OpenUP and OpenUP/Basic Describe differences between unified processes and Agile methods Describe how OpenUP is a Unified Process that incorporates some Agile methods that have proven effective Describe what Agile elements are incorporated into OpenUP Introduce the 4 principles and link to appropriate concept pages Describe how OpenUP is a open source project and link to www.eclipse.com/epf Describe core concepts and link to appropriate concept pages Describe the process lifecycle Iterative development Use cases Risk
The WIL and use cases should be referenced as primary artifacts in the process

I understand the concern that the introduction page is a bit empty, but that was somehow intentional. The reason is we wanted to make the graphic appear as first thing seen, then links to additional info would appear around.
The proposal presented here will tend to clutter the page a bit. Question is, in an introductory page, will someone spend lots of time reading through all the page or is it better for an intro page to be minimalist and point to relevant info?
This probably falls in my domain...sigh
forgot to re-assign this bug to myself rather than inbox...sigh again

Created an attachment (id=56871) Draft OpenUP Introduction Outline
I have taken some of the existing OpenUP introduction content and combined this with some elements of Jim's proposed outline to create a new draft outline for the OpenUP introduction.

Most of the recommendations are reasonable for the introduction although I believe some of the topics are more appropriate for the "getting started" section. The introduction should answer the questions What is OpenUP Who is it for? What is it for? How does it compare to other processes?
IMHO, nuts and bolts content such as lifecycle, use cases, WIL etc are probably better dealt with in the "getting started" section.
Also I agree with Ricardo that we want to avoid clutter on our intro page. After all, this intro content will most likely be read once.
I think we need to re-organize the home page such that there is no text on this page explaining OpenUP, just the tree browser, the quick link icons, lifecycle diagram, and the "round table" diagram. These provide four perspectives to OpenUP. If we are going to put the lifecycle diagram on the home page, then we should remove the lifecycle quick link icon.
Re-assign issue to Jim Ruehlin as per agreement during Friday Jan 19th telecon.

Introductory text has been written and an outline in the form of a hierarchy in the tree browser has been created. More text should be written in Construction to fill this out. The new hierarchy should be verified for usability.
When this entry has been verified, I recommend creating a new bug to address writing the remaining text and verifying all introductory text.
This has been addressed by changes in the tree-browser and welcome page.
The introduction and tree browser have been updated to provide better introductory information. Issue closed.

bug.short_desc: XML Parsing stuff (xml_sax_parsing.php) Needs to report errors in the XML document

long_desc.thetext: The current implementation just silently fails when invalid content is encountered in the XML. Since the implementation is based on the SAX APIs provided with PHP, it is probably far too much work to attempt to recover from the error. Committed in Phoenix.
Moving to Community/Website

bug.short_desc: PDOMCPPFunction returns wrong getParameterTypes

long_desc.thetext:
PDOMCPPFunction returns the wrong results in getParameterTypes(). Types from ICPPFunctionType.getParameterTypes are not the same types as ICPPParameter.getType() (from IFunction.getParameters()).
For the differences, see the method CPPVisitor.createType( IType returnType, ICPPASTFunctionDeclarator fnDtor ). There are a couple of modifications that occur to do with cv-qualification and pointers.
This will be important if PDOM bindings are expected to be used interchangeably with normal bindings during semantic resolution. Particularily in the case of overloaded functions.

There is no need to store the parameter types as specified in the source in the index, rather than that I changed the code to store the modified types. This way the correct types are returned on the call getParameterTypes().

bug.short_desc: [API] Fup of bug 156352, ASTParser.createASTs(...) should be able to specify if all bindings must be completely resolved

long_desc.thetext: The user should be able to tell whether createASTs(...) should resolved all bindings (including the bindings for the units in the queue) or not.

I was not aware of the semantic shift of the fix for bug 114935, but in the end, I think the original ASTParser.createASTs(..) method should be deprecated, since it really changed in an incompatible way between 3.1 and 3.2.
If bug 150657 is implemented, then I guess we wouldn't need this special API.
*** Bug 155399 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

bug.short_desc: allow adding multiple existing tasks at once via Add Existing Task wizard

long_desc.thetext:
Would be handy to add a new category to Task List populated from plain list of bug ids/keys (e.g. comma-separated "156123,128333,98012").
Right now I can achieve the same either with manually created category and adding bugs one by one, or to have a named query in a repository. Both are not that convenient.

I wonder what is the use case for this and which repository connector you need that for?
By the way Mik, I noticed that "Add existing repository task..." action is not available trough Ctrl-N/Ctrl-Shift-N wizards.
It's just a convenient way to add few existing tasks at once instead of adding them one by one. It doesn't seem to be tied to any particular connector.

I just don't recall having a need in something like that while using Mylar for over a year now. So, curious where those task ids would come from?
The closest use case is when you have query in the web browser and need to drag-n-drop links from that query to the task list...

Working in a team, there are different ways to communicate set of bugs you would like to draw attention to. It's not always handy to pass urls around, and plain lists of bug numbers are much more suitable. If a person gets "1,2,3,4" on IM and needs to go to repository and to create a query, switch back to Eclipse and to add a query to Task List -it's just odd, too many actions.
If there's a need to add single bug (apparantly, there's a need, hence the action to add single task), some day there's a need to add few, and to accomplish that at once ;)

For our own usage and the usage we have noticed I have not seen users need to work with a collection of bugs that can not be represented as some kind of query, and we generally encourage using queries and discourage adding task explicitly. But if this is a use case that is important for others than we would be happy to take a patch that allows the dialog to accept a comma-delimited list, and adds each item in the list. Notes on contributing are here:
http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/Mylar_Contributor_Reference

Well, first of all I don't see much difference between query based on substring in the summary field and query based on a list of bug ids. Both are queries to me, and hence "encouraged" way to proceed. Next, provided I can't create arbitrary query from Mylar (at least with Bugzilla - e.g. I can't specify keywords), I'm forced to switch to browser in addition to Eclipse/Mylar to overcome the limitation.
Though I'm pretty sure the use case of adding few bugs by id is essential to any person overseeing complex project (let alone interacting with non-technical people addicted to using whatever medium to pass bugs around), I'm stuck trying to figure out what's the difference is between query in a form of "*GraphicalEditPolicy*" and "1,2,3"...

To create an arbitrary query in Mylar use the Web UI to create it, then do New -> Query -> Create from existing URL and paste in the URL.
So now I'm curious, would you prefer to add multiple bugs by ID, or would you prefer to be able to create a query that's formulated by specifying IDs?

I do know about named queries; the drawback using them is that you need to go back and forth between browser and Eclipse, plus, they take additional "maintenance" efforts, e.g. deleting once no longer needed.
Choosing between multiple bugs by id and extended query wizard I'd take former. Perhaps, it's just a matter of personal taste or a habbit overgrown to addiction ;), nevertheless, it seems to be much more simple to implement (let user enter more than single id in the existing dialog) and is connector-agnostic.
Artem, seriously, if you so desperate about this, why don't you contribute a patch? It would of taken you less time then convincing people who never saw need in this feature. :-)

It sounds like we have converged on the approach and I updated the summary accordingly.
Eugene: we can't expect all users who are willing to provide feedback and discussion on how they want the tool to work to contribute patches, and when one user clearly outlines a use case, even if it is a corner one, it is worth discussing. Although as you point out for some cases like this it can actually take less time to contribute the patch and for us to apply it than to discuss it ;)
Artem: we make it really easy to contribute and create patches, since the project committers tend to focus on streamlining and improving most common use cases. If you or anyone else is interested in providing a patch for this refer to the following on getting your workspace set up: http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/Mylar_Contributor_Reference

I wish I could insist on patches in our project (GMF) ;)
Guys, I doubt the time I'd spend checking out the code, getting acquainted with the codebase, looking for particular class/method, adding tokenizer and for, finally creating a patch and eventually you reviewing/committing it is anyhow similar to that of yours fixing this right away.
I'm not "desperate" about this functionality ;). It just seems nice idea to me; and the reason I spend time talking about it here is that I personaly don't like bug reports when committer can't get any feedback from the bug submitter.

It appears to be a simple enhancement. I would be happy to take a look at this after getting a solution to bug#165088, since it think perhaps it could deprecate the current "Add Existing Task" wizard.

(In reply to comment #12) > It appears to be a simple enhancement. I would be happy to take a look at this > after getting a solution to bug#165088, since it think perhaps it could > deprecate the current "Add Existing Task" wizard.
That is another reason I didn't want to rush into this. :-)

Artem: we do not insist on patches. But we have limited resources and are largely a volunteer project, and ince there are so many use cases and workflows for working with tasks what many users have been doing is contributing workflows that make Mylar work better for them. To support those efforts we try to be very pro-active about supporting and applying patches.
Willian: I'll put this in your queue for now in case it will be a quick fix after you are done with bug 165088.
Created an attachment (id=56202) Patch
Created an attachment (id=56203) mylar/context/zip
Can we also allow spaces as delimiters? Just in case...

Patch applied and verified, good stuff Willian. For now I changed the label text to: "Enter Key/ID (use comma for multiple)".
Willian: could you please update the Users Guide with a note on this use case? http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/Mylar_User_Guide

(In reply to comment #18) > Willian: could you please update the Users Guide with a note on this use case? > http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/Mylar_User_Guide >
I can do it, but actually there is no mention to this "Open Repository Task" on this guide.
I can add a section if you want. Do you have a good screenshot?

Done.
http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/Mylar_User_Guide#Open_Repository_Task_dialog
Yes, it would be good to add a screenshot because I have a feeling that many users don't know about this functionality.

bug.short_desc: [Doc] Document changes in how presentations (or layouts) work.

long_desc.thetext:
in the CVS Workspace Synchronization dialog,
It is no longer possible to change the layout to 'flat' from 'compressed folders'
The option has been moved to the synchronization preferences under the 'workspace' tab
Here is a quote from the documentation which explains the expected behavior
================== Begin quote ================== Workspace Model: displays a resource based model. Layout options for this model can be controlled from the Preferences dialog in the drop down menu. The layout options for the Workspace model are:
>Flat layout shows all the out-of-sync resources as top level items. >Tree layout shows the resource hierarchy as it is shown in the Resource Navigator. >Compress Folders shows changes grouped by project and then by folder. This results in a hierarchy that is at most three levels deep with folder paths being compressed into a single level (similar to a Java package).
================== End quote ==================
Clicking apply and ok has no effect.
This is a majorly annoying problem as it is a feature I use all the time in earlier versions of Eclipse.

I'll need to update that doc as things have changed a bit. I also want to investigate reintroducing the Flat layout in the new model-based sync.
P.S. This wiki entry explains the difference between the new and old sync and has intructions on how to get the old behavior back.

bug.short_desc: [Webapp] Make top-level book icon clickable in Help system

long_desc.thetext:
In the help system, the top-level bookshelf view's icons (the blue books) aren't click-able. That is, if you click them, the book doesn't expand or collapse. You have to click the text to have anything happen. This is inconsistent with a) the user's expectation set by most web interfaces b) the Dynamic Help view, where the top-level book icons are clickable c) the help system's lower-level book icons, which are clickable.
Can you extend the linkiness to include the book icon on the bookshelf?

Isn't this one duplicated with another Bugzilla to "Make behavior of expand/collapse the same for tree entries"?
Is there any core or user experience reason to keep a different paradigm ("book" icons) for the top level vs the nested levels? I mean, what are the pros/cons for the top level to be different than the nested nodes +/- icons and behaviors?
--Lee Anne
I'd looked for existing bugs but couldn't find one. Still can't find the one you're refering to. Got a bug number?
We are working on making the table of contents look more like a regular tree, which will fix a number of problems including this one.
I had this one in mind: https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=127102 for details.
Yes, this does look the same as Bug 127102. I'll leave this bug open for now since the code with the fix is being rewritten and I want to verify that this stays fixed.

The TOC view now has an expander ( a '+' or '-' icon ) at each level of the tree including the book level. This solves the underlying problem that users don't immediately know how to open a book. For consistency with other Eclipse trees I'm not planning on having clicking on a book perform an expand.
I'm going to close this bug out with no plan to fix but if you try the new tree (which is in the latest integration builds) and still find yourself wanting to click on a book icon you should reopen the bug.

bug.short_desc: [EditorMgmt] can we remove IURIEditorInput?

long_desc.thetext:
URI cannot be resolved to a type org.eclipse.ui.workbench/Eclipse UI/org/eclipse/ui IURIEditorInput.java line 39 1163611136718 748662
This is API that was added in 3.3. Since URI is not part of J2ME Foundation 1.0, can we do without this API?
I have no idea... this is the first I've heard of this class. Tod, you checked it in... can you give some history?

No we can't - it was aded for EFS support.
We could move it to IDE though. Adding Dani and Michael to check if we need this at the workbench level.

What I was asking for (see bug 111887) was a file editor input for file stores. When we discussed this we thought URI would be a nice generalization. We might back off from IURIEditorInput if it hurts too much. Putting it into IDE is wrong from an architectural standpoint. Instead we could introduce IFileStoreEditorInput at the IDE level which has a getFileStore() method and wait until we get concrete request for IURIEditorInput.
The org.eclipse.core.filesystem plugin requires a 1.4 JRE because it uses URI. I see no choice but to put IFileStoreEditorInput into IDE... Dani, in which plugins do you need IFileStoreEditorInput?

We have the same problem with IEditorLauncher - it can only open an editor on IPath. If we wanted to support providing editor launcher for URI it would logically go in workbench. It seems that some parts of the editor framework make the bad assumption that editor inputs are files in the local file system.

I'm a little confused by John's comments. Can't we just do what Dani proposed in comment #3? This is what I refer to:
> Instead we could introduce > IFileStoreEditorInput at the IDE level which has a getFileStore() method and > wait until we get concrete request for IURIEditorInput.

>It seems that some parts of the editor framework >make the bad assumption that editor inputs are files in the local file system. Well, so far there are neither dialogs nor editor inputs (with the exception of this ongoing work) that can handle arbitrary EFS. Just Platform Text's internal implementation to support the local FS.
Currently we are in the middle of actually trying to add better support to open editors via the new the (I)FileStoreEditorInput. I guess what John wanted to express is that there are plug-ins that - once the support is there - would like to open an editor using IFileStore (or URI) without depending on the IDE plug-ins.
Here are some related issues: - bug 116414 - bug 49495

(In reply to comment #7) > ... I guess what John wanted to > express is that there are plug-ins that - once the support is there - would > like to open an editor using IFileStore (or URI) without depending on the IDE > plug-ins.
This sounds like a reasonable request, but would require creating a new plug-in.
We cannot use URI in org.eclipse.ui.workbench, so IURIEditorInput has to be removed, or moved into another plug-in. I would like to find a solution for this as soon as possible since it is blocking bug 121434.

I said the wrong thing in comment #4 - I meant to suggest simply moving IURIEditorInput into IDE. To me IFileStoreEditorInput and IURIEditorInput are almost equivalent, except IFileStoreEditorInput ties the client to an eclipse-specific abstract (IFileStore), rather than a general Java class library abstraction (URI), so the latter seems preferable to me.

John so it sounds like the best course of action is to remove IFileStoreEditor and replace it with IURIEditorInput in the IDE.
Do you agree?

There is currently no IFileStoreEditorInput - this was just suggested by Dani in comment #3. Currently we have a FileStoreEditorInput class in IDE plugin, and IURIEditorInput interface in workbench plugin. We need to move IURIEditorInput to the IDE plugin, and fix up any existing references accordingly.
Lets move it to IDE as suggested.

I have deprecated IURIEditorInput in the workbench and moved it to org.eclipse.ui.ide.IURIEditorInput. I will remove the workbench version when I get the go ahead from Dani.
Fixed for build >20070214
This should get a PMC +1. Since the API is being removed from one plugin and added to another, it's an API change. I agree it's a necessary change because the current API requires a 1.4 EE.

>This should get a PMC +1. You need to send your request to 'eclipse-pmc@eclipse.org' and if no PMC votes -1 in 24 hours it means GO. This was agreed on in last weeks arch call to speed up the process.

I spoke to Tod about this one yesterday. I wanted him to verify that none of the intended consumers of this were going to now be constrained to have a dependency on the IDE that they otherwise might have avoided. I.e. Could this be a problem for RCP apps?

Michael Valenta and I were talking and his feeling (which I agree with) is that we should leave IURIEditorInput in the org.eclipse.ui package but move it to the extensions in ide.
That way if at any time we either step up to 1.4 or add a 1.4 extensions plug-in the workbench ide is not in the name and we have no API breakages to worry about.
I am going to reopen this pending feedback on this and approval from the PMC when we are happy.

Just make sure to coordinate the change as otherwise you will break the build: Platform Text now uses FileStoreEditorInput at several places and expect it to inherit from org.eclipse.ui.ide.IURIEditorInput.

Michael's suggestion makes sense to me. It's quite possible workbench will be able to move to at least Foundation 1.1 in the future, which contains URI. At that point we would be able to move the interface down to workbench from IDE without breaking anyone.
Dani I am going to move IURIEditorInput after the integration build submission this week - I will synch with you to find a good time to do this.
Let's do it today as soon as you're in, so that we have it in the next I-build.

IURIEditorInput moved to org.eclipse.ui in the ide plug-in so it now has the same signature but is in a different plug-in.
I will remove all of the deprecated classes before the next I build.
Adding Darin as this may affect ant
Adding Darin (S) as there are references to FileStoreEditorInput in Ant, which implements IURIEditorInput.
Darin, I checked your code and verified that it is not affected by the latest change.
ide version of IURIEditorInput deleted for build >20070228
Verified in I20070320-0010
