bug.short_desc: General - Remove Content Describing Subprocesses

long_desc.thetext: This information is only useful for process engineers and does not give practitioners any value. There's a discussion about this on the EPF newsgroup.
This should probably be in a method authoring plug in

OK, this bug is not only about cleaning up some text. If we are supposed to get rid of subprocesses, to what extent we will do this?
1) Remove custom category called subprocesses? [Y|N] 2) Re-write the section in the Roadmap that describes these 4 subprocesses? [Y|N] 3) Replace round table graphic in the front page by something else (e.g. the round table listing artifacts)? [Y|N] 4) Refactor the library to get rid of subprocesses (content packages and process packages), turning it back to have one content package per discipline? [Y|N]
Anything else? Please vote [Y|N] in questions 1) - 4) above.

During the "General and Overarching issues" conf call on 3/12 this item was discussed. My take from the discussion is that we should do some rewording, but still keep the pages so the hyperlinks from the round table graphic would still work. We should reword this so we don't call it subprocess. It'd be better positioned as 'area of concern'. Still a good way to explain to explain the round table graphic.
So for the questions 1-4 in comment #2 we have: 1) Don't remove it, just reword it. 2) Remove the content from the roadmap page 3) Keep the graphic in the front page 4) Keep the library structure as it is for now.

I agree with all Per's comments.
As we talked about the concept in a concall, I noted that a key value of the sub-processes is when you are first introducing OpenUP. Once people have a handle on the process, they will be thinking more along the lines of capability patterns or the responsibilities of some particular role.
Based on that "value in early learning" idea, I am thinking we should shrink down the top-level of the treeview by dropping the sub-processes under the Getting Started item.

Changes added to CVS. Someone, please verify. At the end, I reworded sub-processes to layers. Area of Concern seemed wordy, and since we think of these as ways to slice the content, I thought calling those as layers wouldn't be bad. Anyway, layers are not part of the metamodel, so when presenting OpenUP to an audience, there's freedom to call them something else :-)
I reopened the bug since the term subprocess is still used on the guidance page when you select Intent, Management, or Solution.

(In reply to comment #6) > I reopened the bug since the term subprocess is still used on the guidance page > when you select Intent, Management, or Solution. >
I'm not sure I can find this guidance page you are referring to. I found the word sub-process in the method packages though. I'm committing to CVS, can you please verify? Let me know if you still see any occurrance.
Verified by reporter. Closed.

bug.short_desc: General - Add the term "Collaboration" to the glossary

long_desc.thetext:
This should be a quick hit for M6.
Also this bug was assigned to epf-content-inbox, so I have re-assigned it to myself...
Accepted...

Here is the definition of collaboration I am proposing for the glossary....
Collaboration is much more than a group of people working together. Collaboration is a group of people working together harmoniously towards a shared common goal. A healthy team environment facilitates effective collaboration. A healthy team environment aligns the interests of project participants (development team, quality assurance, product stakeholders, customers) and helps project participants develop a shared understanding of the project.

After some feedback from Jim.....
Collaboration is much more than a group of people working together. Collaboration is a group of people working together harmoniously towards a shared and clearly understood goal. Members of a highly collaborative team consistently remove attention from personal agendas to focus their energies on team goals.
A healthy team environment facilitates effective collaboration. A healthy team environment aligns the interests of project participants (development team, quality assurance, product stakeholders, customers) and helps project participants develop a shared understanding of the project.

bug.short_desc: Drawing issues with transparent images on Linux GTK

long_desc.thetext:
This issue only presents itself on linux (GTK) with advanced graphics set to true. It does not occur on Windows. Occasionally on a redraw, transparent images are drawn incorrectly (transparent areas appear in the wrong colour). The images come from both GIF files and SVG files. See the attached screenshots for examples.
I have been able to reproduce the issue using RHEL4 and have had reports of the issue in Ubuntu 6.06 and SUSE. The issue is easily reproduceable in GMF, but I've had no success creating an example of the issue in SWT only (by drawing the offending images with SWT directly and forcing redraws and drawing other shapes on the surface). I also tried updating Cairo and GTK on my linux box, but that didn't help.
I have attached a straightforward GMF example of this bug which corresponds to the screenshot labeled drop_shadow_gif_image.png. In this case, the drop shadow around the figure is drawn incorrectly when other redraw events occur (eg the selection changes or tooltips/action bars appear). You will need to have GMF, EMF and GEF installed in your target environment to build and run the example. The Callisto Modeling project bundle is suitable and available at http://www-128.ibm.com/developerworks/eclipse/downloads/
Test Case execution instructions -------------------------------- 1. Launch eclipse with a new workspace 2. Select File->Import->General->Existing Projects into Workspace 3. Select the archive file downloaded from the bug report (bugExample.zip). Three projects should be added. 4. Press Finish 5. Select run and create a new Eclipse Application configuration 6. Run the newly created configuration 7. In the newly launched eclipse application, create a new empty project 8. Right click on the empty project and select New->Example 9. "Node Diagram" should be at the top of the list, select it and press Next then Finish 10. Using the palette click on "Node" and then click on the diagram. A box with a drop shadow will be created.
Depending on the last action, the drop shadow around the box will be drawn incorrectly. Certains actions such as selecting and then unselecting the box, or hovering over the editor surface until the action bar appears will cause a redraw which may or may not incorrectly redraw the drop shadow.
GMF uses a transparent GIF to draw drop shadows around figures. The SWT calls to draw the drop shadows are made in org.eclipse.gmf.runtime.draw2d.ui.figures.RectangularDropShadow.
Created an attachment (id=53926) Bug Example
Created an attachment (id=53927) SVG Image Issues Screenshot
Created an attachment (id=53928) GIF Image Issues Screenshot
A duplicate of the "cario doesn't draw my image" bug?
What bug is that Steve?

bug.short_desc: [Markers] Tasks View/List should provide a comment field and be "attachable" to specific projects

long_desc.thetext:
More than once when defining a new task I wanted to save some remark, URL, or some code snippet taht I had found with it. Adding a comment or note field to user-defined tasks might make them a lot more useful.
Another option I'ld love to see is to be able to "attach" tasks to or "filter" tasks according to projects currently open (I open and close projects a lot to have "more focus" in many views (e.g. problems) and selection boxes, e.g. when selecting classes to extend or such).
It should be possible to define "global" tasks (always listed and not attached to a specific project) and other taks, that "belong" to a specific project, i.e. which are only shown when a specific project is open. For this it probably would make sense to allow to specify an element or a location for user-defined tasks (i.e. pick a project and optionally an element and location). Currently these fields are shown in the tasks creation dialog but are grayed out. If one picks a location there the task should only be listed when that location (or its corresponding project) is currently open.
Michael
There are currently no plans to work on this although we would be happy to review patches

bug.short_desc: [Workbench] Project copy doesn't validate location and uses invalid location as default

long_desc.thetext:
Build: I2006114
1) Create a new project whose location is outside the workspace (say c:\temp\p1). 2) Select the project in the Navigator, and Hit Ctrl+C, Ctrl+V. 3) The project copy dialog opens. Accept the default and hit Ok.
-> An error occurs because the location overlaps the location of the project being copied. There are two problems here:
a) If the project is not in the default location, it should populate the dialog with a new location that is different from the original location (such as c:\temp\Copy of P1). I.e., it should provide reasonable defaults that don't cause the copy to fail. b) The location provided in the dialog should be validated using IWorkspace#validateProjectLocation. The Ok button should be greyed out until a valid location is supplied.
CCing Susan: in case this is code you are still working in.
I'm not working in here now, but I'll check against M2 behavior and see if this is a regression I caused.

Verified this bug occurs in M2 and in 3.2.1.
The default location proposal is not valid, yet there is no initial validation performed. (For example, backspace and retype the last character of the project name, and now the location is validated).
The default location is chosen in ProjectContentsLocationArea using the existing project's location name. So it will always be wrong when using it for a project copy.
I'll leave this up to the current owner to sort out...
Not a Vista specific problem

Created an attachment (id=59971) Patch attachement
Nobody was assigned to this bug, so I tried to create a patch. I hope that I understood well, what the problem was about. Please verify my work.
Thanks for the patch!

Jakub this patch does not update the path.
I think the problem here is that the new location is the old location by default when it should be based on the new name.
For instance if I copy a project Foo in c:\foo I will get a name Copy of Foo but the default directory will still be c:\foo not c:\copy of foo.
I think a better solution would be to always use the default location in the copy dialog as there is no good way to guess another one.

bug.short_desc: Tons of PDOMNotImplementedError exceptions

long_desc.thetext:
Eclipse 3.3M3, CDT HEAD: I'm getting tons of PDOMNotImplementedError exceptions all coming from PDOMCPPEnumeration.isSameType. Here is a typical call stack:
org.eclipse.cdt.internal.core.pdom.dom.PDOMNotImplementedError at org.eclipse.cdt.internal.core.pdom.dom.cpp.PDOMCPPEnumeration.isSameType(PDOMCPPEnumeration.java:91) at org.eclipse.cdt.internal.core.dom.parser.cpp.CPPSemantics.resolveFunction(CPPSemantics.java:2298) at org.eclipse.cdt.internal.core.dom.parser.cpp.CPPSemantics.resolveAmbiguities(CPPSemantics.java:2021) at org.eclipse.cdt.internal.core.dom.parser.cpp.CPPSemantics.resolveBinding(CPPSemantics.java:627) at org.eclipse.cdt.internal.core.dom.parser.cpp.CPPVisitor.resolveBinding(CPPVisitor.java:941) at org.eclipse.cdt.internal.core.dom.parser.cpp.CPPVisitor.createBinding(CPPVisitor.java:186) at org.eclipse.cdt.internal.core.dom.parser.cpp.CPPASTName.resolveBinding(CPPASTName.java:52) at org.eclipse.cdt.internal.core.pdom.indexer.fast.PDOMFastIndexerJob.addSymbols(PDOMFastIndexerJob.java:188) at org.eclipse.cdt.internal.core.pdom.indexer.fast.PDOMFastIndexerJob.doParseTU(PDOMFastIndexerJob.java:109) at org.eclipse.cdt.internal.core.pdom.indexer.PDOMIndexerTask.parseTU(PDOMIndexerTask.java:142) at org.eclipse.cdt.internal.core.pdom.indexer.fast.PDOMFastIndexerJob.parseTUs(PDOMFastIndexerJob.java:249) at org.eclipse.cdt.internal.core.pdom.indexer.fast.PDOMFastReindex.run(PDOMFastReindex.java:50) at org.eclipse.cdt.internal.core.pdom.PDOMIndexerJob.run(PDOMIndexerJob.java:67) at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:58)

long_desc.thetext:

" Running the BIRT Engine in Console ---------------------------------- In order to run the BIRT engine in command you should:
1. set BIRT_HOME to the directory where BIRT SDK is extracted. 2. generate the report by run genReport xxx.rptdesign xxx.rptdesign is the design file. if the design file is in the current directory, you have to specify it by .\xxx.rptdesign "
I have some comments on improving this: 1) Instruction 2 above is not right. The genReport is not in the directory where BIRT SDK is extracted.It is under the sub directory ReportEngine. 2) Actually the BIRT_HOME should point to the ReportEngine directory. 3) The genReport.sh correctly takes care of #2 , ie by setting BIRT_HOME to the ReportEngine directory. $JAVACMD -cp "$BIRTCLASSPATH" -DBIRT_HOME="$BIRT_HOME/ReportEngine" org.eclipse.birt.report.engine.api.ReportRunner It may be best to call the directory where the BIRT SDK is extracted as $BIRT_SDK_HOME or some such variable and not confuse it with BIRT_HOME.

bug.short_desc: JUnit/Plug-in tests do not allow plugin root as source folder.

long_desc.thetext:
JUnit/Plug-in tests do not allow default package names.
JUnit/Plug-in test wizards do not force the user to specify a package name.
When the user creates a JUnit/Plug-in test with a default package (e.g. empty value), the test class generator displays an error that the package a cannot be empty. This is a problem for several reasons:
1) It is a regression since users were permitted to use the default package in previous versions.
2) JDT permits classes to be created in the default package.
3) Users may want to use the default package.
4) The JUnit/Plug-in test wizard allows the user to specify the default package (e.g. empty value) (the user is only warned that the default package is discouraged).
PELASE OMIT THE ABOVE DESCRIPTION!

Defect Description:
JUnit/Plug-in tests do not allow plugin root as source folder.
When the user creates a JUnit/Plug-in test with the plugin root as source folder, the test class generator displays an error that the package fragment root is not the source folder. This is a problem for several reasons:
1) It is a regression since users were permitted to use the plugin root as source folder in previous versions.
2) JDT permits classes to be created in the plugin root as source folder.
3) Users may want to use the plugin root as source folder.
4) The JUnit/Plug-in test wizard allows the user to specify the default package (e.g. empty value) (the user is only warned that the default package is discouraged).
Steps to reproduce:
1) Create a JUnit/Plug-in test with the plugin root as source folder.
2) Remove the generated package.
3) Attempt to regenerate the test class.
Reassigning to the component leads to triage for 4.4.
Has the priority for this defect been recently reviewed given its severity? If not, please take a few minutes and reevaluate the priority.

Will be included in the 4.4 plan.
Please target to a 4.4 iteration.

The CreatePackageFragmentChange used during the refactoring had a bug in its isValid() method. Now the method validates properly a source folder and in particularly when this source folder is a project.
Updating hours worked
Reporter: Please verify and close in preparation for shutting down the TPTP 4.4 release. Thanks.

There are couple things still outstanding:
-The user can still modify the Source Folder field in the new JUnit/Plug-in test suite wizard to point to the root folder. For example, create a new JUnit/Plug-in test suite in a Java project named Test, the user can modify the Test/src value to Test or Test/ with only any warning (e.g. Source folder is not a Java project). This part is valid. However, the generated JUnit/Plug-in test suite does not have the root folder as its source folder. For example, Test or Test/. If so, the JUnit test class could be generated, albeit not compiled until the root folder is set as the source folder in the build properties. This follows the JDT usability.
As such, reopening to be addressed in 4.5.
Decreasing the severity/priority since most of this issue have been resolved.
Included in 4.5 plan for the Test Tools project.
